clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Two Doses of Intranasal Dexmedetomidine as Premedication in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Two Doses of Intranasal Dexmedetomidine as Premedication in Children - a Double-blinded Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Intranasal dexmedetomidine has shown to be an effective sedative when used prior to anaesthetic induction as premedication. 1mcg/kg intranasal dexmedetomidine was used in previous study and it produced satisfactory sedation in more than 50% of the children at the time of anaesthetic induction with no adverse effect. In this study we aim to compare 1mcg/kg with 2mcg/kg intranasal dexmedetomidine in children. We expect more children would attain satisfactory sedation prior to anaesthetic induction when higher dose is used.

study_design_info.masking: Double Blind (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: proportion of children attained satisfactory sedation

clinical_study.condition: Patient Between 1-8 Years Old Undergoing Elective Surgery at Queen Mary Hospital

arm_group.description: 1mcg/kg intranasal dexmedetomidine administered 45 minutes befoe anesthesia induction
2mcg/kg intranasal dexmedetomidine given 45 minutes prior to anesthetic induction

intervention.description: Intranasal dexmedetomidine is given as premedication prior to induction of anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 1-12 years old
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) 1-2
- Elective surgery
- Children with autism or pervasive personality disorder
Exclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) 3-5
- Allergy or hypersensitive reaction to dexmedetomidine
- Known cardiac arrhythmia or congenital heart disease
- Mentally disabled
